completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: We will now hear argument in Veneman against the Livestock Marketing Association. Mr. Kneedler.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Justice Stevens, and may it please the Court: Congress enacted the Beef Promotion and Research Act in 1985 in the midst of a serious depression in the beef industry. The beef industry found itself unable to respond to that situation through the promotion of its products. Congress responded to that situation by establishing a government program of promotion, research, and consumer information. In the Beef Act, Congress prescribed the central message for advertising under the Act, Congress established a government body, the Beef Board, to administer and implement the program, and it placed the program under the control of a Cabinet officer, the Secretary of Agriculture.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Mr. Kneedler, will you tell us how this case differs, if it does, from what was before the Court in United Foods? What meaningful distinctions do you find?

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well, the important distinction is that the two grounds that -- on which we are defending the statute here were not addressed in United Foods. In particular, the government speech argument, that what I've just said goes to, that the Court specifically did not address because it had not -­

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: We've never addressed that in --

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: In none of these cases, and -­

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- in these cases -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- have we?

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: The Court has not. And we think that that is -- the critical point about this -- about this case and these programs, these are government -­ these are programs of government speech. As I said, Congress, itself, prescribed the central message. Congress established the government board, all of whose members are appointed by the Secretary, to administer it.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Does it remain government speech even if you don't say, "This is your government speaking"?

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: It -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: If you say, you know, "America's cattlemen are speaking," is it government speech?

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: It does -- for purposes of this Court's government speech doctrine, it does. And I think --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Why is that? I mean -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: And the Court -- the Court's decision in Rust, I think, is the best illustration of that.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Yes, but Rust did not -- Rust was not a case in which the doctor was saying, "This is my personal opinion, not the government's." And here, as Justice Scalia pointed out, there is an affirmative effort to say, "This is -- this is paid for by" whatever it's called, the cattlemen's group or the beef group, which affirmatively indicates that it's not government speech.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well, it -- all those statements say -- and there are advertisements in the record that say that the advertising is funded by America's beef producers, which is, of course, accurate, because they -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Well, it's accurate -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: -- they pay for it.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- but it also contains the implication that who -- he who pays is the person whose speech is being broadcasted.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well, but, again, in Rust, the doctor who spoke -- I think the patient who went to see the doctor for counseling would have -- would have assumed or believed that the doctor was -- in the immediate encounter, that the doctor was speaking, and yet the Court, in its subsequent cases, has regarded Rust as a situation of government speech. But the important point about what you've just asked is that any concerns about the tag line in the advertising does not go to the constitutionality of the statute or the beef order. Neither the Act nor the order requires that in the advertising. And if the Court was to perceive that as a problem, the right remedy would not be to invalidate the Act, but to, instead, provide that there should be some different identification -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Yes, but some people -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: -- on the advertising, itself.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- may be more resistant to an -- to an ad that says, "Your government wants to eat -­ wants you to eat more meat," than they are to an ad which say, "The meat producers would like you to eat more meat."

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well, I -- and I think in Rust, some people would have been resistant to the idea that your government wants you to engage in family planning, but what the -- what the Court said about Rust was that the government had established a program with a central message about counseling. That was then carried out by private individuals. Here, this case is much stronger than Rust.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Well, but if you -- if you say the Act can be -- say, because this is just an as-applied challenge, you're asking us to assume that we can put on a label that's not true, "This message is brought to you by your friendly Department of Agriculture." That isn't accurate.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well, it would be accurate -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: And you're having us save the statute by just putting a label on it that isn't accurate.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well, they're -- I'm sure that a label could be devised that would -- that would be accurate. The -- first of all, they are approved -­ specifically approved by the Department of Agriculture. The -- certainly, the Act and regulations provide that the Secretary must approve every contract, every project for advertising. And, beyond that, the USDA approves all advertising, all copy -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: But, Mr. Kneedler -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: -- that is actually to be used, so there is specific approval by the Secretary.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: But there is -- there's another tape put out by the government, on meat, and that -- what is the government speech? Usually, the government has a position, and is presenting it. Here, we have America beef producers has a label on -- "Eat meat." But if you went to the Surgeon General, probably that message would be "Eat meat moderately." So what is the government speech? I don't know another case involving a claim of government speech where the message that you are saying is the government's is not the message that the government is putting out when it's dealing with its concern for public health.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well, the government, in the concern -- in situations where it may be concerned about public health, doesn't say, "Don't eat meat." It -- there may be nutritional standards. And USDA does have nutritional standards that it advises people to adhere to. But what the government is doing here is facilitating a situation, facilitating promotion of a commodity. There is a structural defect in a market like -­ a market for a fungible commodity, and I think it's important to understand what Congress was responding to here. When you have a fungible commodity, when you have a lot of small producers, no one of those producers has an incentive to advertise -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Mr. Kneedler, is meat fungible? Or -- I think there are some steak houses that might disagree with that.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well, there are -- there are -­ there are, to be sure, different cuts of meat, but the -­ but the basic -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: I mean, even quality of meat within the -- some is tougher than others.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: It's not like milk or wheat.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: But Congress could reasonably determine, under this statute, that there are -- that there are -- that beef has many things in common, that it is a generic problem -- or generic food or generic commodity, and the industry -­

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: At some level, it certainly is, I suppose. But, just as in wheat or corn, there are different brands and different qualities. But I suppose it's still fungible, in a broad sense.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: It is fungible in -­

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: May I ask you whether, in deciding the government's speech doctrine, is it the Secretary's formal right to control, as set out in the statute, that we look to, or do we look to the Secretary's actual record of oversight and participation?

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: We think the -- we think the formal legal control is sufficient. And it -- the Secretary has the responsibility to approve -- under the statute -- to approve budgets, to approve contracts, and to approve projects. And USDA does, in fact, go beyond that and determine whether particular advertisements will be -- will be issued. But we think it's only necessary to look what the statute requires. But the testimony in this case shows that, in any event, USDA is extensively involved in the development of the advertising under this statute, by extensive consultations with the Operating Committee and the Beef Board in the development of the project. So there -- this is an integrated effort within the Department of Agriculture.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Is it at all possible to do here what has been done in the union cases, where -- I mean, it's pretty hard for me to believe that there aren't -- that meat -- that cattle growers don't, by and large, like beef. I mean, maybe they have a ideological objection to people eating beef, but I doubt it. They probably object to some content. So can you segregate that? I mean, in the union cases, the bar cases, they try to segregate where there really is an ideological objection from the cases where really all that the objector wants is not to pay the money. And so they work out a system. You know, you pay so much for your dues anyway, you just don't pay that pro rata amount, where you really have an ideological objection.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well, I think that -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Is it possible to work that out?

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: What has -- what has been proposed by the -- by the Respondents in this case, of course, is to make it voluntary, so that people -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Yes, but, I mean, if you make it -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: -- can opt out.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- totally voluntary, what you're going to discover is, all of a sudden, the beef people, rather than write a check, will say, "Oh, you know, I make -- I raise cattle, but I don't think people should eat beef."

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: That saves them the money.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well, and I -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: And I tend to doubt that that's their view.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well, and -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Some may view -- object to certain content. So I'm asking if it's feasible to work out -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: I think it -- I think it would not be feasible. It would -- it would enmesh the Department in difficult judgments and time-consuming -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: It would be -- in the union cases, it's hard enough. It's a -- the good-of-the-order exception is the way it works in the union. And in the bar thing, I think it would be hard to -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Absolutely. And the Court made a similar point in Southworth, where it specifically declined to impose, on the university, a requirement to make judgments that would enable people to opt out in particular cases. And we think that the problem here would be even greater. But they would be particularly great under Respondents' proposal that individuals who don't want to pay, without even having to express an objection, because the whole system would collapse. This is a classic collective-action, free-rider problem.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Mr. Kneedler -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: What the numbers -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- can I come back to Rust versus Sullivan? You say that that was a government speech case? I had not recollected it as a government speech case.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: This Court -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: This is government subsidizing speech by private organizations, and it chose to subsidize one type of speech, but not another.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Yes -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Did we say, in the opinion, that this was -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Not in Rust, but in the Court's subsequent cases, Rosenberger, Southworth -- in particular, in Velazquez -- this Court said that Rust has come to be understood by the Court as a government speech case, because the government prescribed the message, and it's government speech whether or not the government speaks for itself or enlists others to transmit the message.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Well, for the precise purpose at issue here, I think it makes a lot of difference. You can fund private people for some things, and not fund them for others, and it doesn't make whatever they say government speech. I think that's a -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: But -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- I think that's a really -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: -- but there's really no -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- strong proposition, that whenever you're subsidizing any private enterprise, the speech of that private enterprise becomes public speech.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: There's really no need to get to that point here, because the Beef Board, which is the entity that does the speaking, is, I think, unquestionably a government body. It's established by special statute under the Lebron test. All of its members are appointed by the -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: That's fine. But what you were using Rust for was to establish the proposition that in order to be government speech, it -- you don't have to -­ you don't have to say, "This is the government speaking."

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well, I think -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: And Rust doesn't stand for that.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: -- Right -- I think, as this Court has come to explain Rust, as being a species of government speech -- but, as I say, there is no need -- there is no need for the Court to get to that situation. And the fact that the government is the one in control of the speech here critically distinguished -- distinguishes this case from cases like Keller and Abood.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: This is a question perhaps more for the Respondent than for you, but I would like your comment on it. Suppose the statute were changed and there was a dollar-a-head assessment on beef, and it just went into the general funds of the United States Treasury, and then they used part of that money -- they had more money for beef advertising, and the government did the advertising. What would the Respondents say about that?

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: I think -- I think they would say that that -- that there's something different about general taxes and excise taxes or focus taxes. But I don't think there's any basis in this --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: But why can't -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: -- in history or -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- why can't you just do that? Or is your answer to me, "Well, then, it's just formalism, and you might as well rule for me now?"

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: I'm sorry, do -- maybe I misunderstood your question.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Why can't the government -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Were you asking why focus -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- why can't the government adopt my solution?

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well, I -- and maybe I misunderstood. Was it -- was it paying for it out of general taxes or taking this money and putting into the focus -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: It's put into the general fund of the -- of the Treasury.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: I -- they may say that that's the same thing, but I -- they were drawing a distinction between paying for it out of general funds -- income tax or something -- that we all would pay for. They say that's the solution, rather than having the industry, that benefits from the advertising, pay for it. Not only does the industry benefit -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: But then you'd come within the protections of Frothingham versus Mellon, and Massachusetts versus Mellon, if you did it that way.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Yes, there would be standing objection -- objections at that point, but we think, in terms of the merits of the argument, the notion that a person would have a First Amendment objection to paying an excise tax because of the uses to which the excise taxes are being put is really extraordinary and finds no basis in cases like Abood and Keller, which have to do with private association -- an association with private speech --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: But then you could -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: -- no government speech.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- simply restructure this Act to get to the result you want.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Yes. If that -- but the funds that are raised are public monies. They don't go in -- they're not deposited in the Treasury. But in the Joint Appendix, there is a reproduced -- an AMS, Agricultural Marketing Service, circular that explains how these public monies -- and calls them "public monies" -- are to be disposed of. And it describes the Beef Board, this governmental body that receives the money, as being the custodian for the Agricultural Marketing Service and handling these monies. And Congress and the Secretary have imposed strict limitations on how those funds can be deposited. So whether they go into the general Treasury or whether they're handled in this way is really a matter of fiscal and revenue and internal governmental policy that I don't think that -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Mr. Kneedler, this theory is one that wasn't brought up at all in Wileman, if I remember correctly. And in United Foods, it was brought up too late, so the government -- so the Court didn't entertain it. The argument that you're making today, I take it, would necessarily displace United Foods as having any kind of a continuing -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Yes, because the government did not reach the government speech -- or the Court did not reach the government speech argument in United Foods. And, in fact, United Foods is back, on remand. That was a reversal of summary judgment for the government. It's back, on remand, and is being stayed, pending the outcome of this case on government speech. So there would not be an inconsistent result in -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: You wouldn't want to treat beef and mushrooms inconsistently.

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Well -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: But there is -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: -- I think -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: -- the public perception of these ads -- it says, "Eat meat" -- it's quite different from saying, "Your government wants you to buy meat." And the United States isn't saying that. So -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: But what the -- what the United States is doing is responding to this classic collective- action problem by establishing a government program to meet the situation where the industry, itself, will -- is unable to conduct the advertising because of -- because of, what I said, the fungibility of the product -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: But then -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: -- and all.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: -- isn't it more realistic to describe this as the government facilitating the private speech of the many people in this industry who don't have a big budget to advertise on -­

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: I think -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: -- on their own?

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: -- doctrinally, it is government speech. It has the -- it has the benefit of enabling the promotion that would have happened in the industry, but for the collective-action problem to occur. But it is government speech under this Court's decision. If I may -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Do you want to save your time?

completeLines.speaker: KNEEDLER
completeLines.speech: Please.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Mr. Garre.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: Thank you, Justice Stevens, and may it please the Court: The First Amendment does not prevent the government from speaking out in order to revive and expand the market for the nation's most important agricultural product.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: If we can just continue on government speech, because that's where -­

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- where we left off. It seems to me there is something offensive about making a particular portion of the public pay for something that the government says.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: Justice Kennedy -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: It ought to be out of the general fund.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: Justice Kennedy, the assessments in this case are imposed on a class of people who sell particular commodity -- cattle. In that respect, they're no different than the types of assessments the Federal Government has been imposing for centuries on the same of commodities, from the first tax the Federal Government imposed on whiskey to the excise taxes on gasoline producers today. And Respondents concede you could do this out of general tax revenues. They concede that you could have a government speech program funded by excises on certain commodities, like cigarettes or alcohol. There is no basis under the First Amendment to carve out a different rule in the case of beef.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: What I'm saying, it seems to me that the government speech doesn't seem to me to advance your argument very much, because it has problems of its own.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: Well, we agree with the government speech doctrine, although we also think that the Court can uphold the statute under the intermediate-scrutiny analysis. It makes perfect sense for the government to be speaking out in order to correct the market problem that Congress identified in the midst of a two-decades-long depression in the beef industry. Take the BSE incident last year. BSE imposes a potentially catastrophic and overnight impact on the beef industry. In response to that threat, because of the beef checkoff program, the government was able to respond immediately with the funds necessary to respond on a national scale, not only through promotion -- and this is an important part in which this case is different from United Food -- only about half of every checkoff dollar goes to promoting beef through commercial advertising, like the "Beef, it's what's for dinner" campaign. The rest of that dollar goes to things like producing information to consumers about the safety of U.S. meat, the -- addressing the health concerns imposed by BSE and other potential diseases, like E. coli; going to open up foreign markets so that we can export beef -- beef exports have risen dramatically under this program -- and going for things like research in order to identify an early- detection system for BSE. In United Foods, this Court emphasized, at least three times throughout its opinion, that the only aspect of the program that was -- the dollar was being collected for was commercial advertising. And, Justice Stevens, I think you emphasized that in your concurrence, as well. And this program is much more holistic -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Yes, but, I mean, that -- the part that's good can't save the whole thing, any more than in the -- in the union case, the fact that some -- the union dues could be used for some permissible purposes, saved the dues that were being used for impermissible purposes. You -­

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: Well, the union -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: You don't want to just save half of this program, do you?

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: Well, certainly saving half is better than scuttling the whole -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Oh, all right.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: -- thing, Justice Scalia. But the union case is -- the speech that was -- that this Court held could not be funded -- and, after all, in those cases, the message was controlled by a non-government entity, the union or the state bar. But there, you're talking about political and ideological speech. Here, we're talking about beef production -- producing -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Well, what's the objection to, whenever you have an ad, you put a little thing in the corner, and it says, "This advertisement is paid for by the beef industry under a regulation, X-23, of the Department of Agriculture"?

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: Justice Breyer, the program would do that if this Court held it was necessary -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: And it wouldn't -­

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: -- under the First Amendment.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- tough, would it?

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: But -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: All you'd have to do is have a little thing -- and it would just say, "USDA requires this, under the program," and then the whole problem goes away.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: That's correct. But let me make a few additional -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: All right.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: -- points. First, as Mr. Kneedler emphasized, nothing in the statute, the regulation, requires the ad to say that they're funded by America's beef -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Well, I -- we realize that. I mean, we're getting into it because there's at least a potential constitutional problem here.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: And let me make another -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: As you respond to Justice Breyer's question, would you go the step further and say, Why isn't one possible solution to this difficulty we're having about government speech a requirement that if you want to justify it as government speech, you put in the advertisement, "This is the government's position, paid for by the beef producers"?

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: The government isn't hiding from -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: No -­

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: -- the messages in its pro-beef ads. It -- Justice Souter, the government could do that, but it's not hiding from this message. We think that if the Court -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: It seems to be. In fact, there was an indication in the brief that the government had taken the position that if the government came out front and said, "Hey, we're urging you to eat more meat," that, in fact, it would be very unsuccessful in doing it. It seems to want to hide the ball here.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: Well, the government does do that, Justice Souter. Last year, during the height of BSE crisis, the President, from his ranch in Texas, urged Americans to eat more beef and told Americans that beef was safe. That's the same message that went out, supervised by the United States Department of Agriculture, through the Beef Board, to communicate -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Did he -­

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: -- message.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: And who paid for that? Did these people pay for that?

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: The President's message was paid through general tax dollars. The message under this program is paid through the assessment. It's the same message. The message under the Beef Board is carefully controlled and supervised by the United States Department of Agriculture. If I could make a point -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Well, let's be honest about it. Let's be totally accurate. It's not going to say, "The government believes this." The government may not believe it. What it says is, "This message is brought to you by the Beef Association under the -- under a program requiring contributions to advertising of the Department of Agriculture."

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: And -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Nobody will even know what that means, but it has the -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- it has --

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: Well, that's good.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- it has the virtue of being totally accurate.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: That's right. Every single ad that we're aware of, has the beef check, which is the sign that the beef -- or the reasonable observer would know that this is a statute passed by Congress containing a message that Americans should eat more beef, that beef is nutritious, that's disseminated under a program that's carefully supervised and controlled by the Secretary of Agriculture.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: The important thing is, you have no objection to doing that.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: We would not, but we also think -­ and if the Court made that clear in this case, it wouldn't be a basis for invalidating the statute; it might be a basis for sending it back or an as-applied challenge. Importantly, we -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: But what it -- what it would -­ what it would be a basis for, at least within the confines of this argument, would be a basis for your government speech claim in the sense that you wouldn't be basing a government speech claim on what is really a misrepresentation.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: It -- we don't think it's a misrepresentation. The speech is funded by America's beef producers. The Respondents in this case, the centerpiece of their First Amendment argument -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: No, including those who don't want to fund it and who don't agree with the message. I mean, the problem here is that by making that representation, you indicate that this is the message of the people who are paying for it. And some of the people who are paying for it do not wish to convey that message.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: We -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: That's the misrepresentation.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: With respect, we would disagree. There's no reason to believe that a reasonable observer would think that just because an ad says it's funded by the nation's beef producers, every single one of the 850,000 individual cattle producers in this country agrees with every single statement -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: But what they would -­

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: -- of the message.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- what they would, I think, assume is that, in the name, the beef producers do, in fact, agree with this, and this is their message. What they would not assume from it is that it is what you and Mr. Kneedler are claiming, the speech of the Government of the United States. They certainly wouldn't infer that.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: We think it's fair to assume, as the Court would under the establishment clause, that they're familiar with the act of Congress that makes it its message as well as a program. A critical point on this attribution argument is that it's not supported by any single piece of evidence that Respondents, themselves, have put into the record in this case. Their First Amendment objection is to the content of the ads. There's not a single piece of evidence in the record purporting to make this attribution argument that the public would attribute to the ads to them. It's not in the complaint in this case, it's not in their own affidavits, it's not in the -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Well, maybe -­

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: -- in the -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- maybe it's not because they didn't know you were going to be defending on the basis of government speech. That's what's getting us into this.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: Well, I highly doubt that, Justice Souter, because the First Amendment claim was added in response to the United Foods case, and this case was developed, from the outset, on a government speech theory.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Which wasn't a government speech case.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: But it -- the case was tried under the First Amendment, under a government speech argument. But -- so the fact that Respondents didn't put -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: This case, not United Foods. Because United Foods, the Court said it -- it was not legitimately before us.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: That's correct. But my point is that the First Amendment case proceeded after United Foods. The government's central argument in the trial was government speech. The one time attribution came up -­ and this is at pages 46 and 47 of the trial record -­ Respondents' own witness testified that the public was not likely to attribute the message of the pro-beef ad to its organization of beef producers. So if the Court finds that attribution is a constitutional concern, it's no basis to bring down the act of Congress on the record in this case. The -- I want to emphasize, if I could, that the program in this case has been effective. The record establishes that the beef checkoff has had a statistically significant impact on increasing consumer demand for beef and an increase in prices. That's contained in the expert testimony of Professor Ward, at pages 100 and 173. The record also shows that for every checkoff dollar spent on the program, there's more than a 5.67 rate of return back to the beef producers in the form of increased prices for cattle. The Beef Board's 2003 report suggests -- finds that the price of a fed steer increased by more than $200 in the past few years. This program has worked. Thank you very much.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Thank you. Mr. Tribe.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Justice Stevens, and may it please the Court: As I was listening to some of the questions about whether it would solve the problem to be more candid and say, "This is your government speaking," I thought I would begin with that question, rather than with an overview of government speech. You'll recall Wooley v. Maynard, of course, in which the State of New Hampshire, without sensing the irony of its position, said, "We'll put you in jail if you do not say, 'Live Free or Die' on" -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: But that was -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- "your license plates."

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- that was an individual attribution. You, yourself, had -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- had to carry this message. Now, here you want us to think of some cowboy -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- going into the bar, and he gets jeered by all his friends because he likes beef.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, Justice Kennedy, my -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- my point -- my point was going to be that a footnote on the license plate saying, "This is New Hampshire speaking," would not have helped. But one of the central holdings, as I understood it, of United Foods, independent of government speech, was that although there is a difference between having to say something yourself, having to put it on your car, and having to pay for it, that difference does not go to the existence of a First Amendment speech objection -- not an association objection, but a speech objection.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Let's first address the question you said -- you said you were going to address, whether in order to be government speech, within the meaning of our cases, it has to be identified as such. Is that really true? I mean, you know, in World War II, Bob Hope would appear in movie theaters and say, you know, "Buy war bonds?"

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Yes, I don't -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: "This is Bob Hope. You people ought to go out now" --

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Justice Scalia, I think, although it's an interesting digression about whether the government is being candid, the objection here has nothing to do with that.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Okay, so it is -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: But being the government -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- it is not essential -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: It may be.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- that government might -- in order to be government speech, the government does not have to identify itself as the speaker.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Yes or no? Yes or no?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: I think the answer is yes, it must identify itself, but it doesn't help, because -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Well, it doesn't --

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- the government -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- we understand that you have a First Amendment claim, which you're going to have even if we say, "This is not government speech." I think the whole point here is to decide whether this is even -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: No, no, Justice -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- an issue that should be disposed of on any grounds other than candor.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Justice Souter, I think that we're getting off track by assuming that it helps for it to be government speech. My point is that a central theme of this -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Well, just indulge us. I mean, some of us think it makes -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Let me -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- a difference -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, but -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- and I would -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- but let me ask you whether -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- I would like to know whether it is essential to its character as government speech that the government's say, "This your government speaking."

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: It depends on the purpose for which you are acting whether it's government speech. In Rust v. Sullivan, even though I think you're certainly right, Justice Scalia, that in that opinion it wasn't called government speech, in order to rationalize it, in Rosenberger and Velazquez, it was so described. But the question there wasn't, "Can people be made to support it?" The question, rather, was, "Can the government insist on staying within the terms of its grants and saying you can't talk about abortion?" When the question is, "Can the government force you to support it," the "it," if it's government speech, doesn't help. The First Amendment makes it a harder case for them, not easier.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: It does it all the time in general taxes. Every -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- time we pay general taxes, we're supporting government speech -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Of course.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: -- we may not agree with.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: But the Court has said there is a fundamental difference between being singled out, as in Wooley, to have a license plate, as in Pruneyard, to have someone on your premises. In Pruneyard, the Court said that one of the reasons it's okay to require someone to allow a private speaker onto the premises is that he was not required to support a government slogan. When it is --

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Yes, but there it -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- government speech -­

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- there it is your car, your property. That's not this. This is a generic ad on behalf of beef.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: That was true of --

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: I think there is -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- that was true of United Foods.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- there's a world of difference between this and having something put on your license plate or in your -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Justice O'Connor, I would be much more offended by having to put it in my license plate. But if I were raising cattle, and I were told, as they were told in this case, "cattle equals beef; that's all it's worth, and that's why we won't let you, in these ads -- we won't let the ads, that you have to pay for, increase the demands for cattle; only beef" -­

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Well, I don't even understand your argument. Would you still be if the -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: I haven't made it.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Well, you're trying.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Would you still be here if there were distinctions made on behalf of free-range beef or, you know, "Our cattle" -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Oh, yes.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- "never had a" -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: The most important distinction -­

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- "medicine" or something like that? Would you still be here if those distinctions --

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, if it -­

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- had been made?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- wasn't generic -- there's no way for them to have an ad for every imaginable different kind of cattle in one set of advertisements. I just think -­

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Well, I'm just -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- it's a -­

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- asking you if, theoretically, some attention had been paid to the different kinds of producers -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- would you still be objecting?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: We would object, fundamentally, if they did not emphasize American beef. That was our first objection. They said that they don't want to emphasize American beef, because, in cross-examination, the officer of the Beef Board said, "Consumers might actually have a preference for American beef. That would be irrational. We don't want that." And so all of those cattle ranchers can say that, "We're proud of it being American." They can't get that in there. And the other principal thing is that they don't think of themselves as selling sides of beef. Some of them are selling dairy cattle, some of them are selling -­ even if it's going to, in the end, be in the slaughterhouse -- we all die someday -- their fundamental belief is that these are animals, and they're to be cared for. And the reason that that makes a difference -- the reason that it makes a difference that they can't even advertise -- try to make live cattle more attractive to buy -- is that the collective-action problem, if that were relevant here -- I think that was really resolved by United Foods -- but the collective-action problem is really created, not solved, by what they're doing. Because the structure of the market is that there are a few concentrated meat-packers. Something like four slaughter 80 percent of the -- of the cattle in the United States. They have the bargaining power. And in the record, their support for the findings of the District Court, that when the demand for beef goes up through these generic ads saying, "Eat beef" -- although they certainly don't say, "Your government says you should eat beef, beef, beef" -- but when the demand for beef goes up, the profit is pocketed by the meat processor, the meat packer, the restaurant, the supermarket. And these guys still end up taking their cattle to market, and often having to pay a dollar checkoff, even though they can't even get the price of the -- of the cattle back. So -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: But would it -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- the free rides are now taken by the people who don't pay -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- seems to -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- the processors don't pay anything.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: I understand that a person could have an ideological objection to the content of the ad. But the ad, itself, is an effort by government, in this area, to regulate a commercial matter, not a license plate that says, "Free Speech, or Die," or "Freedom" -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: But it regulates speech, Justice Breyer.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Yes, I know. Right now I'm asking -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: They don't -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Well, my question is, does it make a difference for the point of distinguishing, or not distinguishing, "Live Free, or Die," and similar ideological matters -- does it make a difference that the fundamental aim of the program, and 99 percent of the way it's carried out, has to do with simple advertising, commercial advertising, the regulation of a commercial matter, commerce --

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- does that make a difference?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: I think it makes an emotional difference.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: But no legal difference.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Not in the context of forcing people to pay.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: So, in other words -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: It makes a difference --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- in other words, a program that is a regulatory program regulating commerce, we should no longer think of that, though we tend to think of it as quite different in the way we approach the First Amendment -- we no longer, in your view, should?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: No, no. I think, certainly if we are regulating economic transactions and only dealing with speech in a purely ancillary way -- that is, we're regulating sale, transactions -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: We regulate advertising. We regulate commercial advertising.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Right, but the -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: The Federal Trade Commission -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- network -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- didn't you say that just the fact that you call it commercial speech only means that when you are regulating problems of a transactional kind -­ deception, overbearing -- then the fact that it's commercial speech makes a big difference. But you can't just generically say that because something doesn't fit your idea of what's ideological -- I mean, to these ranchers, the ideology -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: I didn't say -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- is different -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- I didn't say they had a -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: But whose -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- commercial objection.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- whose line -- whose line between ideology and commerce will -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: I am asking. In analyzing the program, there are some things for it, and there are some things against it. And in trying to make that weighing, I do think it's different, because the basis of the program is commercial regulation. And so I want to be certain, in your view, that's either correct or incorrect.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: I think it's -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: If it's incorrect, I want to know why.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, I think it's -- if one were just weighing and didn't have a structured set of principles on the balance in favor of it, I think, you're right, we can't -- they're not trying to induce ideological conformity. This is not a case where they're trying to enforce what Justice Jackson calls "the unanimity of the graveyard." It is a case where the spirit of the government is in the right place. The government is trying to facilitate collective speech when --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Well, if it makes a difference, then the lens that I look at this through is called our -­ whatever the second-tier commercial speech lends.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: I don't think -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Have you looked at -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: That doesn't follow. I don't think that follows. It follows that if you were -- if you were writing on a clean slate and were trying to create a wholly new doctrine, one of the things you would look at, I suppose, is that this is not a program designed to create ideological conformity in America. At least the spirit of the program is not that. But the road to hell is often paved with good intentions, and the means, in this case, that was chosen, was not to have the government spend some more money telling people, "Beef isn't all as bad for you as you think." The remedy that they are choosing is to pick a group of ranchers and say to them, "You are the ones who are going to pay, and you are going to pay for" -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Mr. Tribe, would -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- "ads that are in your name."

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- would you comment on the argument that -- what will this do to compelling cigarette manufacturers to finance the advertisements against smoking?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, by "advertisements against smoking," Justice Stevens, if you mean, "Here are the things that will kill you in cigarettes," the kind of thing that's on the package now, it seems to me that it is constitutional, under even cases like Zauderer, to say that whoever sells a product or a service -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: They have to give warning. But why is the -- why is the cigarette analogy different from this case? What is your answer to that?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, it seems to me that no one suggests that the cigarette companies are supporting the ads in California. California is doing exactly what the Surgeon General does.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: Well, it's odd that you can be compelled to -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Say negative things -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- engage in speech that you don't agree with. Now you're saying that the more -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- disagreeable it is to you --

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- the more legitimate it is. That's -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: I think if you're -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- a very strange argument.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, it may be strange, but I think that there have been stranger things. The reason that it's true is that if you go around doing things that might endanger people, it's entirely justifiable for the state, as part of its non-speech effort to protect people -­

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Well, do you -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- from harm, to make you give warnings -­

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- do you accept the fact that the government can charge taxes on the sale of cigarettes and compel -- and use that money to tell people that they're dangerous?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, I think that's a much harder case than this, to be honest with you. I think -­

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: We do, however.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, California does that.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: Is that part of what's going on?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: In California, it does.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: So what you're arguing here --

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- is going to have rather a drastic effect on -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, I think the -­

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: -- what's going on.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- drastic effect would be the other way, wouldn't it? If this Court were to hold, despite United Foods, that it is permissible to force people to support speech they don't agree with, as long as that speech doesn't fit our sense of what's ideological, that cuts to roll back Keller and Lehnert and Abood. It's not a small part of the constitutional landscape that would be unearthed. Whereas, think about what is the marginal effect of saying -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: Wait, I don't -- I had not understood you to be arguing, Professor Tribe, that this would be unlawful, even if the money were raised in the fashion that it is, just from the -- just from the cattlemen. And the government's own program used that money to say, "Your government thinks it's -- wants you to know that beef is thoroughly safe. We've done studies. Beef is good for you. You should eat more beef." I thought you -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: No, I do think that would be permissible.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SCALIA
completeLines.speech: That would be permissible?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Because, I mean, technically, it would solve only the association problem. They're not associated with the message. They're still forced to support it, but not in any sense different from general taxpayers. And because that's the case, and because it would be an odd formalism to say that it makes a difference whether we segregate that money or not, seems to me it would follow that if the government is willing to pay the political cost of having the speech be perhaps less persuasive because of -- people's discount for what the government says and of having to get an appropriation from the taxpayers -- I mean, taxpayers are smart enough to know -­

completeLines.speaker: CONNOR
completeLines.speech: No, not that. The same program, but you just have a little tag on the ad.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Like the lockbox? I mean, every -­ I think the taxpayers know that money is fungible. Well, in this case, you mean if you had the program, not from general revenue, but you simply said, on the ad, "This is actually part of a government program"? I don't think that solves any problem, other than deception.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: What's the -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Deception is the -- my constitutional argument.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- what's the difference between the checkoff and the excise tax?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, the checkoff in this case is money that goes to a group, which, though it is organized by the government, purports to represent -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: So the answer is -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- the way it structured -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- where -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- these people.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- where the money goes and who pays out the money for the ad, that's the difference.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, the difference is the whole structure. Keep in mind -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Well, isn't that the -- isn't that the essential difference between the structure in this case and the structure in the case in which the government comes out, saying, "This is your government, saying, 'Don't smoke.'"

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Yes, one -- the difference is that in one case, we've got Congress, we've got the executive, we have one -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- person, one vote. Here, we have a million -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: I know, but take all that out of it -- take all that out of it, and what is your answer to Justice Stevens and Justice Souter? That is, look, like this, you have an organization, the Federal Trade Commission, say, or that the FDA says, on the one hand, (a) broccoli industry, "Fruits and vegetables are good for you; crib death device, "Buy anti-crib-death devices; "Buy car seats for your children"; or, "Don't smoke"; or -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, I mean -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- "Don't buy a crib without a crib-death device" -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- I mean, I think it's -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- "or a car without a car seat."

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: See? One's negative and one's positive. And everything else is the same. Then how do you -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Whether it's -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- what's the difference?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- negative -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- or positive, it's the government --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Okay, maybe it doesn't matter.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, no, it matters, in this sense. When the government puts out a message and puts its credibility behind the message, likely to have to balance -- it's going to say, "A little broccoli, but a little steak." "Don't risk crib death" -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: But I'm not interested -- I got that point.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Right.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: I'm not dismissing it. I understand it.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: All right.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: But I'm not sure -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: So I'm not understanding what your question is.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: Well, my question is, is it implied in what you're argued that it would be equally unconstitutional, in the same way, to tell the cigarette industry to advertise, "Don't smoke," or to tell the automobile industry to advertise, "Buy car seats for your children," or to tell the crib industry to advertise, "Be sure you have an anti-crib-death device"?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: I think -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: And all that, assuming the financing is the same as here, everything else the same, is it implicit in your argument that they're all equally unlawful?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: No. My argument is that you can require the seller of any commodity to include warnings. It does not necessarily follow that you can say to an industry, "You're bad guys. We want you to put on an advertising campaign, and the campaign has to have these characteristics." Forcing them to advocate that people not buy their products, I think, is not the same thing -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Mr. Tribe -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- as forcing them to say -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: -- I thought -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- that it will be addictive or that it will cause cancer.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: But you're saying -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: -- I thought -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: I want to be sure I -- that I understood your answer. You can compel them to make warnings. Can you compel them to pay for warnings that are just industry-specific, in saying, "This is dangerous" --

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: I think so, because I can't see any difference between saying that -- you put on the package, "The Surgeon General has determined that smoking will cause cancer," and saying, "We're going to put on television" -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: But it seems -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- "the Surgeon General" -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- almost ironic, to me, to say that you have a greater power to tell the whole industry to publish something they don't want to publish than you do to let them -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: But that -- Justice Stevens, what -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- pay for what -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- what is -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- 90 percent of them want to say.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- what is the difference between telling them that -- I mean, there may be a critical difference between the point of sale and a generic ad -­ that is, the power to regulate the transaction to make sure it's safe, includes the power to include on the package certain warnings. The moment you step back from that and say that, "Because you're in a dangerous business, you have to publish general warnings to the public," maybe that's where the line has to be drawn, because I agree that it would be rather bizarre -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Are you limiting your point to putting information on the package, or are you saying they could -- could California compel a cigarette -- companies to contribute to a large fund which is just used to by newspaper advertising describing the dangers of smoking? Could they do that?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, I think that the rationale for that would be far stronger than this. The state's power to protect people, in terms of life and health, includes the power to compel -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: Yes, but supposing there are disagreements. We were -- you were talking about cigarettes. But supposing there's a legitimate disagreement between the industry position and the government position -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Okay.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE STEVENS
completeLines.speech: -- could the government, nevertheless, insist on the industry financing advertising advocating the government's position?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, not advocating; reporting what the government position is. I mean, the -- when the cigarette company says on the package, "The Surgeon General has found this stuff is deadly," they're not quite saying, "We agree with the Surgeon General." They've -­ making them fund or support statements that do not reflect their own beliefs, as though it were -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: So, in this case -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- is impermissible.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: -- I take it, it would be okay if the beef producers had to use a dollar a head to put, "Eating too much beef is dangerous to your health."

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, if they had -- well, they're not beef producers. I mean, I am troubled by -- they're -- these are cattle.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: All right, cattle, then -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: All right? And then -- and then they're trying, ultimately, to brand us as though we are slicing these things up and selling them.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: But what's the answer to my question?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: If the question is, can retail grocers be required to put on the beef packages they sell, "The government has determined that the cholesterol content is dangerous if you have more than X," I see no reason why that would be harder -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: In other words -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- to defend than the cigarette package.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: I think the question, or at least the version I have of it -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- is, we have this case, exactly, and the only difference is, instead of getting these people to eat -- say, "Eat beef," what they say do is, they get people together and say, "Don't eat too much beef." I put -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- "too much," because that -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE BREYER
completeLines.speech: -- makes it more realistic. All right, now, does it suddenly become constitutional?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: The program is facially unconstitutional. It is the structure that says to all these people, "You've got to put money into this elaborate structure, which purports to represent you" -- that is, the -- they have all this stuff saying that the Beef Board is related to the industry as board of directors, the shareholders -- "These people, who purport to represent you, will, under the aegis of the government, put out statements at various times." That's facially unconstitutional.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: All right. Consider this theory. The Congress passes an excise tax. It happens to be a dollar head, on the cattle, just like this so-called "checkoff." And the government uses the excise tax revenue to finance advertising, saying -- maybe saying, "Eat more beef," maybe advertising, saying, "Don't eat quite so much."

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Or maybe -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: First Amendment problem -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- talking about the war in Iraq. No, I think that once your taxes enter the general fund, a pretense that it's -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Including excise?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Well, I don't think excise taxes are segregated in any way that makes -- that makes it harder --

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: No, I just want to know what -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- than Social Security.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- your position is. I just want to know what your position is.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: My position is that once the revenue is part of the government's general fund, the government's subject to doctrines that I don't think are First Amendment doctrines about government propaganda -- there may be limits on the government's ability -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Okay, then -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- to defend it.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: He's just going back to -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: Subject to that -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Okay, then it does not have -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- it's not a First Amendment problem.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: -- it's not a First Amendment problem. It does not have the objection that you're raising.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: That's correct.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: Okay.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Is that -- is that an answer to the question that Justice Kennedy urged in the opening argument? That is, it's the same dollar a head, except you call it an excise tax instead of a -- whatever this is called. The same thing, but to say it's a tax. And you're not -- this is not general revenues that you collect from everybody and spend -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: If the structure is they take the money from you and put it in this elaborate machinery which comes out with statements you're forced to support, the statements that don't have behind them the accountability checks of the Federal Government, which has to answer to taxpayers and answer to the public for the stuff it puts out -- that is -- if that's what it is, it doesn't matter what you call it, it remains unconstitutional. It remains unconstitutional because these individuals are forced in a way that taxpayers are not -- forced to be part of a system in which, even if you have footnotes saying, "This is pursuant to the government," a system in which they will be generally understood in just the way Justice Breyer said, "Well, you know, we assume" -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: But suppose -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- that these people -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: -- we don't have that? I mean, could then -- could the government fix this problem this way, saying, "We're going to get the same bucks, but we are going -- and we're going to have the same kinds of ads, but they're going to be labeled, 'U.S. Department of Agriculture."

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: And we're going to eliminate the cattlemen's Beef Board and all of these things -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: Yes.

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: -- that are supposed to represent you -­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: But we are -- but where this money is coming from to pay this is -­

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: I would be happy to represent the cattlemen in that circumstance, saying, "You still have not an associational right, but a right not to be singled out to support government speech." But it would be a different and more difficult claim. One. Two, this Court doesn't have before it the possibility of rewriting all of this. Three, there was a severability provision in an earlier version of the law suggesting that maybe if you could lop something off, it would be okay. But that was eliminated in the current law. And, finally, any attempts to analogize this to the cases like Lehnert and Keller, in terms of remedy, that maybe we can create some scheme where only the objectionable part is returned, is fundamentally incoherent, because what is objectionable here is homogenizing all of these people into some one message, and putting it out through this elaborate structure that purports to represent them.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOUTER
completeLines.speech: May I go back to one of your reasons, which was that they are being singled out to pay for this? They're being singled out to pay for it in the excise tax situation. Do you come to different answers, depending whether it's excise tax or singled out without excise tax, based, essentially, on the ground that there is a point beyond which we simply cannot look behind the expenditure of tax revenue? Is that it?

completeLines.speaker: TRIBE
completeLines.speech: I think that there's a point beyond which, for institutional reasons, it would be very problematic for a courts to say that you could trace the dollars into the treasury and those institutional reasons would be, I think, an instance of under-enforcement of a constitutional norm, because the underlying constitutional principle that you ought not to be able, by some gimmick, to get some people to support speech they don't believe in, that would be there. But the difficulty of having this Court enforce that principle, I think, would be very real.
